EDM OUT EQQ; Budget; EDS: INSERTS after para 14 railway workers barely escape flames; See CP Photo; INDEX: Environment, Social, Forestry, Health; HL:Chisholm, Alta., residents allowed home after forest fire forces them out</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>By Darcy Henton</nitf:byline><nitf:dateline>EDMONTON</nitf:dateline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p>EDMONTON (CP) - Four families in the tiny northern Alberta community of Chisholm were back home Saturday evening after being forced to flee a raging forest fire.</p><p nitf:lede="true">About 12 residents of the hamlet, about 150 kilometres north of Edmonton, had been rousted from their beds early Saturday when flames from the massive fire crept within 400 metres, said Barb Toker, an Alberta fire spokeswoman.</p><p nitf:lede="true">-BODY- Six bulldozers and 50 firefighters defended the hamlet's southern limits Saturday as water bombers hammered back the flames enough for the evacuation order to be lifted later in the afternoon.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Rick Strickland, provincial fire information officer, said several of the residents returned after the winds died down and scattered showers drifted over the fire.</p><p>A fireguard was established around the perimeter of the town and a municipal fire truck waited on standby to protect the buildings in the community.</p><p>Firefighters were also working to protect 12 unoccupied summer cottages in the area.</p><p>Marie Ward, 76, who was back on her farm about a kilometre outside of Chisholm on Saturday night, said she didn't want to leave when the evacuation order came.</p><p>"My girls said, "You better take some things. Take the pictures, Mom.' ''</p><p>They grabbed framed pictures off the walls and photo albums. And at Ward's insistence, they also managed to load up a brand-new rug and her chesterfield.</p><p>"It was just terrible. It was burning so hard that we could hear the roar of the fire when they told us we had to leave,'' said Ward.</p><p>She was thankful her house didn't burn down but she did lose an old cabin about 100 metres away which she used to store Christmas decorations for the yard.</p><p>When she arrived home Saturday around suppertime, Ward said the ground was blackened just 50 metres from her doorstep.</p><p>Her daughter, who has a trailer nearby, was spared the trailer but lost three sheds and her outhouse, Ward said.</p><p>She added her son, who lives on land nearby, walked down a road for several hours Friday to lead his two horses and his dog away from the smoke, before relatives arrived with a horse trailer to pick him up.</p><p>Railway workers near Chisholm had to flee for their lives Saturday before a roaring wall of fire.</p><p>The CN crew was putting out hot spots along the tracks about four kilometres south of the hamlet, riding a truck that can travel on rails. They stopped to water down a wooden bridge over a creek since the fire was still about 2 1/2 kilometres away, said Alister Findley.</p><p>"Fifteen minutes later we looked up and the fire was right up on top of us. We were surrounded. We dropped everything and said, "Let's get the hell out of here.' ''</p><p>They jumped into the truck, put it in reverse and floored the gas pedal.</p><p>"The flames were hundreds of feet in the air,'' Findley said.</p><p>"It was scary. It was really hot in there - the fire was sucking up all the oxygen,'' he said.</p><p>"The suction was so intense. There were these ravens flying over. You could see them get sucked into the fire.''</p><p>They raced back to a crossing by Chisholm where they were able to get off the tracks.</p><p>Chisholm is on the northern boundary of the 120-square-kilometre fire that is now under attack from more than 200 firefighters and a fleet of helicopters, planes and heavy equipment.</p><p>Thirteen residents of Flatbush, about 20 kilometres to the south, remained on evacuation alert, but winds blowing out of the east Saturday had also given them some respite.</p><p>"The wind is going southwest,'' said Strickland. "It is moving the fire away from Chisholm and the Flatbush area, but who knows what is going to happen tomorrow.''</p><p>About 30 people evacuated from farms north of Flatbush on Friday had earlier been allowed to return to their homes.</p><p>Late Saturday night, conditions remained calm, said Toker.</p><p>She said the Chisholm blaze was the largest fire in Alberta this year.</p><p>Meanwhile, Transport Canada investigators were able to return on Saturday to the scene of a plane crash that killed two people who had been helping fight another fire Friday.</p><p>RCMP removed the bodies of the pilot and passenger of a forest fire spotter plane that crashed on the edge of fire burning northeast of Red Earth Creek, but had to evacuate the area when the fire came within half a kilometre.</p><p>RCMP Cst. Cliff Brennan said investigators were still having difficulty assessing the crash site due to adverse weather conditions. Police said smoke had reduced visibility in the area.</p><p>The names of the victims weren't released.</p><p>The Cessna went down in dense forest in a hilly area.</p><p>Strickland said the passenger in the aircraft was a veteran air attack officer who was mapping out a strategy for water bombers to attack the lightning-caused fire.</p><p>"He went up there to do an initial attack on that fire,'' he said. "It is an unfortunate situation.''</p><p>Strickland said grief counsellors have been sent in to help employees and family deal with the situation.</p><p>The deaths are the first involving Alberta firefighters since a firefighter died fighting a blaze near Mariana Lake, south of Fort McMurray, in May 1995.</p><p>Meanwhile, firefighters were fighting 24 fires in the province after one of the driest winters in Alberta history. As of Saturday night, 10 fires, including the Chisholm fire, were burning out of control.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata Only traffic proceeding to local destinations not affected by the fire was allowed to proceed.</p><p>There were 112 fires burning across the territory Monday, all started by lightning and most burning in wilderness observation zones, said fire management spokeswoman Paula Webber.</p><p>A weather inversion in the area meant smoke hovered close to the ground Monday, causing visibility problems for traffic and aircraft.</p><p>Evacuated residents reported to a reception centre in Watson Lake and were being put up in hotels or at private residences.</p><p>Evacuees were asked to close all their windows and doors, shut off their gas appliances, turn the house and yard lights on and close their gates, according to the order issues by the office of the fire commissioner.</p><p>The situation was looking somewhat better in British Columbia, although a new evacuation alert was issued Monday night for an area near Seton Lake, west of Lillooet.</p><p>Some weekend rain allowed firefighters to put out about 14 fires, but that's barely a dent in the 438 that continue to burn.</p><p>Fire information officer Nancy Argyle said some fire crews had to cope with winds of up to 80 kilometres an hour during the weekend.</p><p>"That certainly made for some extreme fire behaviour on some of those fires. Crews in some instances had to pull back for a little bit but they're back on them again today working hard at it.''</p><p>There were just 77 fires burning at this time last year.</p><p>Argyle said the weather outlook is for the return of hot, dry conditions.</p><p>Despite the early, full onslaught to the fire season, firefighters are holding up well, said Kevin Matuga, a fire information officer for the Kamloops region.</p><p>"This is what these guys do and we've got a lot of fit, trained men and women on our fire crews and they're used to this kind of work.</p><p>"We have very, very strict safety issues with our crews and we ensure that the crews maintain a fitness level so they can handle this kind of workload.''</p><p>Matuga said the firefighters would get rest when they need it, but "we're not dealing with any weary firefighters right now.''</p><p>Meanwhile, tourism operators are already concerned that the wildfire season could put another damper on the B.C. industry.</p><p>Michael Campbell, president of the Council of Tourism Associations, said media reporting of the wildfires will play a crucial role in determining whether tourism is healthy or whether it goes into the tank.</p><p>"Bad stories get better air time than good stories. But I think the national media, particularly where you've got television involved, they can tend to inflame the public and they make it much worse than it actually is.''</p><p>(Whitehorse Star)</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier Due to extensive internal damage <br/>to the helicopter, no conclusion could be reached as to what caused the <br/>imbalance. The TSB also found that the helicopter pilot was unable to complete <br/>an emergency landing because of low altitude, and that the longline carrying <br/>an empty water bucket got tangled in trees. <br/>    The TSB is concerned with inconsistent placement of the external cargo <br/>release switch, which increases the risk of pilot confusion during an <br/>emergency when trying to release an external load hung underneath a <br/>helicopter. Furthermore, the report notes that the approved foot pedal backup <br/>release, used as an alternate means of releasing the line and external cargo <br/>during an emergency, is reduced in its effectiveness because the pilot must <br/>take one foot off of a primary flight control to operate it. <br/>    The Bell 204B helicopter operated by Gemini Helicopters Inc. was involved <br/>in forest fire suppression at Bonaparte Lake, British Columbia. At about <br/>11:05 local time, the helicopter departed a staging site slinging an empty <br/>water bucket on a 100-foot longline for the first mission of the day. Shortly <br/>after take-off, the helicopter emitted a high-pitched, oscillating sound.</p><p>The <br/>flight path and behaviour of the helicopter were normal as it went out of view <br/>over some trees. Immediately thereafter, there was the pronounced sound of <br/>main-rotor blades flapping, followed by the sounds of impact with the trees. <br/>The helicopter struck the ground just short of reaching a small clearing <br/>adjacent to a fire road. A post-impact fire ensued. The water bucket was found <br/>in a tree, detached from the longline. The longline was wrapped around another <br/>tree, and 15 feet of the end of the line attached to the helicopter was burned <br/>away. British Columbia Forest Service crews attended the site and extinguished <br/>the fire. The pilot was the sole occupant of the aircraft.</p><p>    The TSB is an independent agency that investigates marine, pipeline, <br/>railway and aviation transportation occurrences. Its sole aim is the <br/>advancement of transportation safety. It is not the function of the Board to <br/>assign fault or determine civil or criminal liability.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content><nitf:body.end><contactInfo>CONTACT: Ginette Thibodeau, Media urn:contentItem:5WCR-F1R1-F103-31F3-00000-00VIDEO: Sproat Lake Fire Department demonstrates sprinkler safety2019-06-19T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:00:34ZLexisNexisCOMMUNITYVIDEO: Sproat Lake Fire Department demonstrates sprinkler safety

SONJA DRINKWATER

SPECIAL TO THE NEWS

A tremendous demonstration of how much a sprinkler system can save lives was put on by the Sproat Lake Volunteer Fire Department on Saturday, June 15.

The demonstration involved two rooms: one room was filled with furniture, a smoke alarm and a sprinkler system, while the other contained furniture and only a smoke alarm. In the mock-up with the sprinkler, the fire was put out in a minute and a half. In the other room, it only took 3-5 minutes to create a deadly scenario where no one could survive.

It takes 8-10 minutes from the time of a call for the fire department to arrive and have their hoses on the fire. The sprinkler room had so little damage that there was more time to vacate. The toxic gases from the fire in the other room were a different story -everything was destroyed, which could have included human and pet life. The SLVFD has roof sprinklers available for purchase, in order to protect your home in the event of a forest fire.

During the open house event on Saturday, Sproat Lake firefighters also put on fire extinguisher demonstrations. Also on site was a vehicle with a thermometer to show how quickly the heat rises in a vehicle on a warm day-at 10 a.m., the temperature was 18 degrees Celsius. By 1 p.m., it was 50 degrees. Firefighters remind you to please leave your pets at home and always check your back seat.

The lucky draw winners on Saturday were Frank Holm (who won a roof sprinkler system) and Cara.St. Remy (who won a fire extinguisher).

urn:contentItem:5T2M-38X1-F105-61PC-00000-00Parry Sound 33 fire being held: how did they do it?2018-08-15T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:00:33ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 1Parry Sound 33 fire being held: how did they do it?

BRITT - Fighting a fire as large as Parry Sound 33 is akin to eating an elephant.

Like a fine-tuned machine it takes a great number of men and women working behind the scenes and at ground zero to bring a, 11,362-hectare fire under control and eventually put it completely out.

On Aug. 15, members of the media were invited to Parry Sound 33 fire's incident command post inside the Britt Legion for a behind-the-scenes look at what it takes to ensure the safety of the crew battling the blaze and the communities they're working to protect.

As of Aug. 15, 195 fire fighters have been working on the fire, 40 of them from Mexico.

Garry Harland, Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry incident commander. said having crews from all over Canada, the United States and Mexico has been paramount.

"It's been really important to Ontario as a bigger picture, because fire crews have been in short supply," Harland said. "The Mexicans are very hardworking, they're very organized, they're very durable ... they're doing dynamite work with our force and they're allowing our resources to fight other fires to especially jump on them quick."

For the last week, Parry Sound 33, a fire about an hour north of the town of Parry Sound that grew to more than 11,000 hectares over three weeks, has been classified as "being held," which means there is a perimeter around the fire and it is not expected to grow.

"You fight a fire sort of like you eat an elephant - in small bits," joked Harland. "Every four-person Fire Ranger crew is responsible for a kilometre of (hose) line, so 3,000 feet. The last couple of days the heat's been brutal."

Crews carry 52-pound hose packs, and 56-pound pumps and they're walking that kilometre, Harland said, many, many times a day. And because the crews camp at the scene, they start early in the morning and work until late in the day.

"For the crew itself on the fire line it's hot, dirty, grueling work," he said. "And once they get the perimeter established, they basically make mud out of the first six inches of the fire perimeter and the next pass they make mud out of the next two feet and the next pass a day or two later they're working in 20 or 30 feet. Subsequently they keep working on this fire until our target is 200 meters free and clear."

Using infrared technology

"Fire crews are really good at sniffing out smoke themselves, they'll have a nose for it as they walk by. Any live fire within a 100 or 150 feet of an experienced fireperson will get a whiff, use the wind direction and track it down."

However, using infrared scanning from the air, Harland said, helps lead crews to areas where they're not already walking.

"In the next week we expect to cross off big chunks of this fire perimeter having successful clean (infrared) scans on it," he said.

Since Aug. 1, Harland said, the fire has been held.

"The focus the whole time has been on the northeast part of the fire, because that's where it was actively spreading."

To maximize on time and efficiency, fire crews are dropped off at the site of the fire and that's where they eat and sleep for up to two weeks.

"You pack your personal pack - your own tent, your own sleeping bag. As a crew you'll have a dining shelter and a cookery kit. You're cooking all your own meals out there. It's kind of like sitting down at the end of the day with your family for that meal around the table," said Heather Pridham, regional strategic analysis management coordinator for the northeast region of the Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry. "You're with the same four people all summer long ... Your incident management team gets deployed as a group and you have the same team members so you get a real level of trust, a real level of respect for each other because you know what the other person is willing and able to do and what should be happening. It's like one big long camping trip."

Crews are sent out with an initial attack kit and a 48-hour kit - the same kits that have been packed by Sobeys in Parry Sound.

The initial kit will last for 24 hours and mostly consists of non-perishable foods like granola bars, fruit leather, trail mix and canned goods while the 48-hour kit has breakfast, lunch and dinner items including fruit, vegetables, meat and dairy products.

Every couple of days the ground crews are "serviced" - fresh food and new supplies go out to the crews and the garbage comes back.

Although the crews' job may seem easy, it's most definitely not, Harland said.

"It sounds easy until you get out there and it's 30 degrees and the humidity (makes it feel like) it's 40 and 50 degrees and you've got that 52-pound pack on your back. Then you start to appreciate how hard the fire crews have worked to contain the fire, consolidate the lines around the fire, and now we're in the extinguishing process. I don't think most folks in the public appreciate how hard the fire crews work and have worked on this fire. If you have one message that you can help me with - these folks have worked really damn hard on this fire and getting this fire under control."

"I'm not smiling," said Brian Miller, general-manager of the River Bend Golf Course Thursday.

His reaction summarizes a golf season that's been blighted by rain, snow and smoke.

Despite having "only nine or 10 golf-able days in wintry September," Miller is still hanging onto the scheduled course closing date of Oct. 9. But he admitted Saturday's Maximum Challenge tournament is "at the mercy" of the winds, which will hopefully dry out some of the wetness that's accumulated on the course.

Miller said the 2018 golf season had a "horrible," wet start and finish. In September, he figured at least three major signature events had to be cancelled because of inclement weather.

And in August many golfers were staying indoors because they had health conditions that couldn't tolerate the forest fire smoke that blew over the city. Even the Discovery Canyon waterfall at River Bend wasn't well used during those "extremely hot" and smoky days: "It was too much for the kids to handle," said Miller, who's hoping for a more typical 2019.

This week's question: Are the B.C. wildfires getting worse from climate change? Only those blinded by the climate change dogma could corrupt something so understandable as a forest fire. Devastating as they are, especially when flames overrun populated areas, wildfires are intrinsic to nature and essential to a vibrant forest.

I am no stranger to forest fires. Growing up in the Okanagan Valley meant enduring the annual August ritual of waking to a sun lost behind a haze of smoke. The air was acrid and the mood foreboding - a primal reaction to fire when out of man's control.

Control is the operative word - man has none. In 1994, while working as a news cameraman I learned this lesson first hand. For two weeks straight, I hiked into the heart of the Garnett Forest Fire in Penticton. Never had I been so close to experiencing the mortal danger faced by B.C. forest firefighters each and every day.

Hearing the crack-crack and roar of a pine tree as it candles into flame just 20 feet away is terrifying -everybody runs. I recall the last member of the fire crew grabbing me by the collar pulling me out as I finished taping the last of my shots.

Any forest firefighter I have ever interviewed would say the real objective is not to control a fire but to contain it, by depriving it of the fuel it feeds on.

Garth points to the 2016 Fort McMurray fire as an example of a new phenomenon called a "megafire" which is said to be a consequence of climate change. Megafires are said to grow bigger, faster and they are more frequent. Yet, never in all my years of covering forest fires did I hear of a speed rating system. If the winds are fast and fuel is aplenty then the fire grows quickly. Simple physics.

The one fact most people seem to agree on is that forest management policy over the past 100 years, which mandated the suppression of all forest fires, has contributed significantly to the buildup of excess fuel loads - exacerbating the wildfire risk. The policy was a failure.

Now the same forest management bureaucrats are aligning themselves with climate change alarmists. To what end? Are we really to believe that fixing building codes, funding climate adaptation and leaping into a post-carbon economy is going to somehow prevent forest fires in B.C.? It's laughable.

Six stories in the news for Friday, Aug. 3

---

TRUDEAU LIBERALS SCALE BACK CARBON TAX

The federal government is scaling back its carbon pricing plan for heavy industrial emitters in a bid to cut greenhouse gas production without creating an incentive for companies to simply up and leave Canada altogether. Last week, Environment Minister Catherine McKenna quietly set out a new plan for industrial emitters which produce more than 50,000 tonnes of greenhouse gases each year, reducing the amount of emissions on which they will have to pay a carbon price.

---

IRREGULAR BORDER CROSSERS COST AT LEAST $270 MILLION

The federal government has spent over $270 million on irregular border crossers over the last year and a half, according to government figures submitted to the parliamentary budget office. The Immigration Department spent more than $117 million since early 2017 and the RCMP says it has spent over $7.3 million since June 2017. Canada Border Services Agency reports it spent about $54.5 million and the Immigration and Refugee Board has spent just under $17 million.

Burning slash piles in the Beaufort Mountain Range northwest of Port Alberni caused concern Thursday night.

The slash piles could be seen once night fell, glowing in an uneven line a few kilometres west of where a forest fire burned for nearly two weeks earlier in the summer.

"We don't have a report of a wildfire but we do know there is active burning in the area," Coastal Fire Centre fire information officer Donna MacPherson said.

"They register the burn with us and then wait for the right conditions to go ahead."

Logging companies or landowners don't have to inform the CFC when they start their burn.

"Sometimes these registrations can be for a year or two," MacPherson said.

The Alberni-Clayoquot Regional District does not issue burning permits within its jurisdiction, CAO Doug Holmes said.

"We understand that anyone lighting a Category 3 machine-piled slash pile (larger than two metres wide by three metres high) must first obtain a burn registration number from the ministry (Ministry of Forests, Lands, Natural Resource Operations and Rural Development)," he said.

"They also have to monitor the venting index which has to be 'good' on the day the fire is lit and 'good' or 'fair' on the following day."

UPDATE: 9 p.m.

The BC Wildfire Service says the Princeton wildfire is estimated at 1,500 hectares as of Saturday evening at 9 p.m.

A total of 60 firefighters, two helicopters, heavy equipment and support personnel were fighting the blaze today.

--

UPDATE: 4:30 p.m.

The number of homes surrounding Princeton on evacuation alert more than doubled today at 4:30 p.m. when the affected area was expanded to include Jura, Erris and Jellico, as well as Missezula Lake, which was put on notice Friday.

There are now 428 homes under evacuation alert.

Sixty homes in total have already been evacuated.

The new alert advisory includes all homes north and east of the junction of Hembrie Mountain Rd and Princeton Summerland Road along Princeton Summerland Road to Shinish Creek Road just south of Chain Lake. This includes all homes on Hembrie Mountain Road, Pinewood Drive and Siwash Road.

Steve Sweeney, who works for the Regional District Operations Centre, said the alert was expanded at the request of the local fire chief.

"It's a precautionary warning if the winds pick up."

A spokesperson for the BC Wildfire Service was not immediately available to comment, but Sweeney said: "from my understanding the fire right now is still very active but it's not moving aggressively."

The lack of wind is also accounting for increased smoke in the area, he said. "The winds are nowhere near what they were yesterday and that's why the smoke is settling in."

--

UPDATE: 2:20 p.m.

No homes are believed to be lost at this time in the 2,000-hectare forest fire burning out of control 10 kilometers north of Princeton.

Princeton mayor Frank Armitage told The Spotlight this afternoon that several outbuildings and "one major barn" have been destroyed.

"At this point we are very relieved that there have not been any reports of homes destroyed," he said.

Approximately 100 firefighters and three helicopters are currently working to control the blaze.

The Kamloops Fire Centre has imposed a complete fire ban throughout its region, including in Princeton.

The ban came into effect yesterday, as the forest fire just north of Princeton raged out of control.

"Get the word out there," said Justine Hunse, communication officer with Wildfire BC. "It's extremely hot and dry, as we have seen."

UPDATE: 11:30 a.m.

The forest fire burning out of control 10 km north of Princeton has reached an estimated 2,000 hectares in size, according to George Elliott, communications officer for the Princeton Volunteer Fire Department,

An additional 40 firefighters arrived on the scene this morning, bringing the number of professionals battling the blaze from the ground and air to approximately 100,

Elliott confirmed that structures have been burned, but could not comment on how many homes or buildings have been destroyed.

So far there are no injuries, he said.

The current strategy of BC Wildfire Management is to attack the fire from the north and southern flanks, said Elliott.

Evacuation orders issued yesterday for 54 homes between Summer Creek Road and Dry Lake remain in effect and while local motels are full, many people have come forward offering places for evacuees to stay.

"We've been able to find some rooms and we have a list of people who have offered [to billet]."

UPDATE: 11 a.m.

BC Wildfire Service fire information officer Tracy Wynnyk confirms the Princeton fire is currently estimated at 1,500 hectares.

--

UPDATE: 10 a.m.

Bill Davies stood in his backyard yesterday afternoon and watched the fire come to him.

"When I first saw it I thought 'what's someone burning this time of year?'"

He said he assumed someone was burning garbage or debris but within minutes "it was out of control."

Davies, who lives with his wife on Seven Mile Road, used every minute until he was evacuated to remove valuables from his home, and then he used his phone to shoot a video of other belongings for insurance purposes.

The couple left the property, which quickly became a command center for forest fire crews, at about 2 p.m.

"The fire was all around us," he said.

By evening the fire north of Princeton was estimated at 200 hectares and declared out-of-control by BC Wildfire Management. Overnight it grew to 1,500 hectares.

Fifty-four families in the area have been evacuated.

Davies said he received a report from the Princeton Volunteer Fire Saturday morning that his home of 22 years is still standing.

He is staying in Princeton with his sister.

Phil Nielsen, another Seven Mile Road resident, was on holidays when he learned of the fire threatening his home.

"We just turned around and came right back."

At 11 p.m. Friday he was allowed behind police barriers to return to his house long enough to rescue the family's cat and dog.

urn:contentItem:5XFK-GR41-JDH1-C497-00000-00Editorial: Airport for Cowichan an idea whose time is not now2019-11-06T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:00:33ZLexisNexisOPINIONEditorial: Airport for Cowichan an idea whose time is not now

It doesn't seem as if the Cowichan Valley Regional District is in much of a hurry to do anything with their report that says a new airport for the area would be feasible. And well they might not be.

RELATED: New airport in Valley "feasible", according to report

Given the difficulty local governments have faced when locating various facilities we can only imagine how problematic it would be to try to find a place for an airport. While there may be a very few people who would not be bothered by the noise of planes taking off and landing, that number is vanishingly small, and we doubt they are living anywhere near where any proposed airport would go in Cowichan.

The report states further that it would need to be close to a major road and to the new hospital, meaning it wouldn't be going in the middle of nowhere, where there wouldn't be any neighbours to be affected.

It seems as if there is a real need, though not urgent, for a new spot for a landing strip in Cowichan for small private aircraft, as the one that's in use right now has a limited lifespan, but the new airport the report talks about would be a significantly bigger facility than that.

It's envisioned as also supplying space for air ambulance, search and rescue, emergency evacuation and forest fire response. These are vital services that we hope the regional district is not waiting on an airport to house.

We definitely don't think there's a public appetite to spend $20 million on such a project. Comments about the story we ran on the subject last week in the Citizen, mostly have people saying they are fine with driving to Victoria or Nanaimo to catch flights, or to hop on the sea plane at Maple Bay. The public does not seem to be clamoring for this.

In terms of economic development, we don't think Cowichan's lack of an airport, which would only be suitable for small planes anyway, is holding the region back. We have easy access to and a relatively short driving distance from already existing airport facilities. This is one report we would not be unhappy to simply see shelved by the CVRD at this time.

First, it was British Columbia that seemed to be ablaze from end to end with forest fires. By midsummer, Saskatchewan alone had spent $77 million fighting forest fires, and in August our TV screens filled nightly with fearful images of flames and pillars of smoke threatening communities in Northern Ontario and Quebec.</p><p>Once fire was our best friend, warming our caves, cooking our meat, casting a fitful light on cave walls where we painted pictures of the animals we hunted. Now fire seems to be our implacable enemy, a natural catastrophe threatening life and destroying millions of hectares of Canada's priceless timber resources.</p><p>Yet I was just talking to a guy who says Smokey the Bear has it all wrong - that forest fires can be a good thing. And I came across some surprising new research showing how you may soon be able to grow some of the world's rarest flowers in your gardens, thanks to fire.</p><p>Michael Feller is an Australian who teaches forestry at the University of British Columbia, and he believes we're altogether too hung up on fighting forest fires.</p><p>Regardless of what Smokey says about campfires and matches, fires are part of the natural cycle and occurred before humans were here. Not only natural, but beneficial, says Feller.</p><p>Forest fires, he says, create the ideal open habitat for animals, from giant moose to tiny mice, fostering the growth of low plants that provide food. Many plants only bloom when the dark, mantle of forest is burned away, and some seeds lay dormant 100 years waiting for that to happen. "Fire is essential for their survival," he says.</p><p>Forget wildlife and pretty flowers - what about houses destroyed and all those hectares of lumber lost!</p><p>No one would argue against fighting fires that threaten settlements. But Feller says too often people build homes in remote locations and then scream for protection when fire threatens - regardless of the cost of fighting the fire.</p><p>And the lumber may not be lost, he adds. Timber can be extracted, even when it's been partially burned, and often fires occur in areas not scheduled for cutting anyway.</p><p>Without fires, says Feller, dead wood accumulates on the forest floor, and when a spark finally ignites it, we have monster fires.</p><p>Feller is especially critical of his own province for wasting money fighting every forest fire; Ontario, he says, is more sophisticated, allowing many fires to burn where settlements are not involved.</p><p>Feller's thinking is right in line with some new discoveries I just learned about in South Africa. That country is one of the richest sources of wild flowers in the world; the Cape region alone contains 8,600 species, two-thirds of which do not occur anywhere else in the world.</p><p>Many of the flowers we grow in our gardens today, such as gladiolus, originated on the Cape, yet thousands more simply refused to grow elsewhere.</p><p>Now the secret has been discovered. Only fire will cause the seeds to crack open and germinate.</p><p>Researchers in Cape Town have learned how to fool the seeds by burning dead vegetation from mature plants, feeding the smoke across seed beds, and sprinkling water to imitate the effect of the rain following the fire.</p><p>So far, 185 species have responded, and the gardeners around the world await the Cape's new bounty.</p><p>But, says Feller, thanks to Smokey and those nightly terror reports on forest fires, we've become conditioned "to think of fire as evil. It's no more evil than water."</p><p>Frank Jones' column appears Monday and Thursday.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata May 02, 2015( Digital Journal: http://www.digitaljournal.com Delivered by Newstex) <nl/> Ukraine said on Saturday that firefighters have extinguished a forest fire that had burned for four days near the Chernobyl plant, scene of the world's worst nuclear accident in 1986.<nl/>

<nl/>Ukraine said on Saturday that firefighters have extinguished a forest fire that had burned for four days near the Chernobyl plant, scene of the world's worst nuclear accident in 1986.<nl/>The fire was completely put out "at 9:00 am on Saturday," the emergencies ministry said in a statement.<nl/>The levels of radiation were slightly elevated at the Chernobyl site, which is about 100 kilometres (62 miles) from the Ukrainian capital Kiev, it said.<nl/>The blaze came within about 20 kilometres (12 miles) of Chernobyl after breaking out Tuesday afternoon, but officials said it posed no danger to the plant and firefighters brought it under control within a day.<nl/>The area around Chernobyl was evacuated after the 1986 blast and the last reactor there was shut down in 2000 but some personnel still operate in the exclusion zone, where work is underway to build a new seal over the reactor site.<nl/>Officials gave few details of the possible cause of the fire but Interior Minister Arsen Avakov said authorities had not ruled out arson.<nl/>The fire struck just two days after Ukrainians marked 29 years since the Chernobyl nuclear disaster.<nl/>
